title: resources
text:
A bunch of random resources collected here until I know exactly where I am going to put them

git/github
I found Happy Git useful

git checkout -b <branch name>
git push -u origin <branch name>

Where “<branch name>” is the name of the new branch. Now you are on a new branch which you can mess with before pushing and then merging with the main one.


customizing
Here are quarto templates, adjusted in the “about” section of the index.qmd file
And here are some helpful markdown basics
Themes from bootswatch to mess with

title: Quarto day 1
text: I just finished my first day trying out quarto, which appears to be a very cool tool using markdown (and code) to generate all sorts of “outputs”, including html (websites), pdf (documents), and many others. As a complete beginner to this, I thought it might be useful to assemble my thoughts on what quarto is, why it my be useful, and how (baseed on my rudimentary understanding) it works. Hopefully this makes it easier for me to teach this to, for example, the people in my research group, if that is a direction we decide to go.disclaimer: all of this may be totally or, even worse, partially wrong so read|interpret|share|believe at your own risk

title: Quarto day 1
text:
Footnotes


I don’t mean this in the sense of someone sitting behind the scenes at a meeting of the UN, but rather any entity that can convert language to meaning: a computer with the appropriate compiler, a web browser, and also a human fluent in the language↩︎
This echos the fun of recursive acronyms (e.g. GNU, PHP) and of a self-replicating 3D printer (RepRap).↩︎
IDE: Integrated Development Environment. There are many other choices and one could also just directly edit the text files. IDEs just have lots of bells and whistles that make editing easier↩︎
